Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Groundwater-surface water interactions in tropical alpine catchments and their influence on sources and stability of water supply during glacial recession
Award.AbstractNarration:
Alpine watersheds and the ice and snow they contain are one of the most important sources of fresh water in the world, and mountain regions that are dominated by glaciers are especially sensitive to climate change. Melting glaciers in the semi-arid tropics currently provide a large component of annual runoff and buffer highly seasonal precipitation regimes, but ongoing glacier recession is predicted to make alpine runoff smaller in volume and more temporally variable, stressing water resources. Previous research suggests that groundwater aquifers in proglacial catchments are an important storage reservoir during dry seasons, and will likely play a dominant role in streamflow generation under future non-glacierized conditions. Despite their importance, little is known about fundamental hydrogeologic processes governing the interaction of surface water and groundwater in proglacial catchments. The investigators on this grant will study the interactions between surface water and groundwater reservoirs in proglacial meadow landforms in the Andes of Peru, estimate their storage volumes, and quantify contributions to streamflow. The research plan integrates a creative combination of field methods to directly quantify groundwater-surface water interactions (GWSWI) in remote, data-poor glacierized catchments and describe the relative hydrologic influence of groundwater storage and melting glaciers. The objectives of the proposed project are to: (1) measure gains and losses of water between stream channel reaches and groundwater stored in proglacial meadows, moraines, talus slopes, and alluvial fans in wet and dry seasons; (2) measure and map subsurface structures, properties, and water content of meadow aquifers and estimate storage volumes; and (3) determine the impact of GWSWI on surface water chemistry and on hydrochemical mixing models used to estimate glacial melt.

The proposed research addresses unknown aspects of proglacial watershed hydrology, and the results will expand the current state of knowledge about groundwater storage and its interaction with surface water resources in tropical glacierized catchments and alpine watersheds. Conclusions from this study could transform alpine hydrologic modeling, which typically ignores or simplifies groundwater storage. The results of the proposed research will be broadly relevant to hydrologists, glaciologists, and physical and human geographers, as well as to water resource managers, development planners, agricultural engineers, municipalities and local governments, indigenous communities, and industrial sectors (hydroelectric and mining). Tropical glacierized mountain ranges are undergoing rapid environmental and demographic shifts and are especially susceptible to climate change and water stress, and this project will contribute to the understanding and prediction of water resources vital to human livelihoods. Education and outreach programs will enhance long-term connections with local community groups, local governments, and Peruvian researchers, and this effort will continue to engage the broader community of water users in the Andes.

This project is co-funded by the Hydrologic Sciences and the International Science and Engineering Programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the tropical Andes, one of the most evident manifestations of climate change is the melting of glaciers and the subsequent transformation of downstream hydrology. Given that ice and snow serve as vital reservoirs of fresh water in alpine watersheds, these changes raise critical concerns for the sustainability of water resources - not only water quantity, but also the quality of the water. The research carried out in this project is needed to better understand the groundwater storage below the glaciers and processes controlling flow between streams and groundwater. This project has broader relevance for managing water resources for domestic supply, agriculture, and hydroelectric power generation.

Previous studies in the Cordillera Blanca of Peru, home to the majority of all tropical glaciers on Earth, have suggested that groundwater aquifers in the valleys below glaciers are an important reservoir that helps form the base flow in streams during the dry season. However, many gaps in understanding remain, given the sparsity of data. This project has combined novel field-based observations and experiments and modeling to measure and describe for the first time the groundwater-surface water interactions (GWSWI) in this remote setting. The internationally collaborative research team comprised scientists from three North American universities working closely with Peruvian scientists in the National Water Authority. Innovative instrumentation was installed and maintained to measure stream discharge, groundwater, and soil moisture as well as climatic variables of precipitation, temperature and humidity. Specific experiments conducted over four successive field seasons deployed hydrochemical tracers, micro temperature loggers and thermal imagery to measure fluxes of water between the stream and surrounding valley aquifers. Geophysical techniques were used to image the underground water storage and flow paths, and digital airborne multispectral (visible to infrared) imagery obtained using custom designed kite and drone platforms were made into 3D topographic maps with cm-scale resolution. 

Project results have been shared in many publications in peer-reviewed journals as well as scientific and public presentations. Graduate students from three collaborating institutions have gained valuable training in designing, organizing, and conducting this research. A newly graduated PhD scientist took leadership of field work and paper writing as a posdoctoral fellow, while four additional PhD students (3 female and 1 male) took on active roles in the project. By involving integrated and multidisciplinary teams working collaboratively on different experiments simultaneously from shared basecamps, there were rich opportunities to exchange ideas. Significantly, these young scholars have each already developed lead authored papers from the project. Findings were also presented to Peruvian government research institutions: the Geophysical Research Institute (IGP), the National Institute for Glaciology and High Mountain Ecosystems (INAIGEM) and the National Water Authority (ANA). The PI was invited to give a keynote address and other team members presented other presentations at the 2016 International Workshop on Glaciers and High Mountain Ecosystems, hosted by the new INAIGEM. Active international collaboration continues, featuring maintenance of the installed instrumentation, and collaborative management of the data.
